p: Zhang et al. in a clinical study of 140 patients found that hypertension and diabetes were the two most common comorbidities in patients with COVID-19 ( 23). The increase in the prevalence of these two comorbidities in patients with severe disease was not significant when compared with those with infections that were not severe ( 23). In a study by Guan et al. 261 patients (23.7%) had a co-existing disorder and 21.5% of them reached the composite end-point (admission to ICU, use of mechanical ventilation or death) ( 24). Of the 15% that had hypertension, and 7.4% that had diabetes, 13.1 and 6.1% (respectively), of these patients reached the composite end-point. It should be noted that hypertension and diabetes are very common comorbidities, no other co-existing disorders were as prevalent in this cohort.
